frontmatter.title: Build a schema
frontmatter.description: Create the blueprint for your data graph

children.value: to define the types of data it includes. For example, the schema for an online bookstore might include the following types:
# A book has a title and an author
# An author has a name and a list of books
In the steps below, we'll set up a GraphQL server that will enforce our schema's structure, and then we'll define the schema itself.
A schema is only useful if our data graph conforms to the schema's structure. Enforcing a schema's structure is one of the core features of
, a production-ready, open-source library that helps you implement your data graph's API.

Now that Apollo Server is prepared to receive our schema, let's define it.
Your GraphQL schema defines what types of data a client can read and write to your data graph. Schemas are strongly typed, which unlocks powerful developer tooling.
Your schema's structure should support the actions that your clients will take. Our example app needs to be able to:
Fetch a list of all upcoming rocket launches
Fetch a specific launch by its ID
Book a launch for a logged-in user
Cancel a previously booked launch for a logged-in user
Let's design our schema to make these actions straightforward.
The schema will go inside the
function (between the backticks). The language we'll use to write the schema is GraphQL's schema definition language (SDL).

Because the schema sits directly between your application clients and your underlying data services, front-end and back-end teams should collaborate on its structure. When you develop your own data graph, practice
Most of the definitions in a GraphQL schema are
. Each object type you define should represent an object that an application client might need to interact with.
For example, our example app needs to be able to fetch a list of upcoming rocket launches, so we should define a

We've defined the objects that exist in our data graph, but clients don't yet have a way to
those objects. To resolve that, our schema needs to define
that clients can execute against the data graph.
You define your data graph's supported queries as fields of a special type called the
type. Paste the following into your schema definition:
type defines three available queries for clients to execute:
query will return an array of all upcoming
query will return details for the
Queries enable clients to fetch data, but not to
data. To enable clients to modify data, our schema needs to define some
type is a special type that's similar in structure to the
type. Paste the following into your schema definition:
type defines three available mutations for clients to execute:
mutation enables a logged-in user to book a trip on one or more
es (specified by an array of launch IDs).
mutation enables a logged-in user to cancel a trip that they previously booked.
mutation enables a user to log in by providing their email address.
mutations return the same object type: a
. A mutation's return type is entirely up to you, but we recommend defining special object types specifically for mutation responses.

es that were modified by the mutation. It's good practice for a mutation to return whatever objects it modifies so the requesting client can update its cache and UI without needing to make a followup query.
Our example app's schema is now complete!

Now that our server is running, we can
its schema types and fields with useful developer tools. Later, we'll also be able to run test queries from those tools.
Introspection is a helpful GraphQL feature that enables you to obtain a server's schema for development purposes. It should be
for servers running in production. Apollo Server disables introspection automatically if the
is a powerful free web IDE for exploring your GraphQL schema and building queries against it:
To use the Explorer with your locally running server, you create a
You'll be prompted to create an Apollo account if you don't already have one (again, Apollo accounts and the Explorer are completely free).
In the form that appears, specify a name for your graph and your local server's URL (
. Studio automatically opens the Explorer to use with your server!
To introspect your server's schema in the Explorer, click the Documentation tab on the left side:
) appear. You can click any type to view its fields and step down into your schema. You'll see that the types and fields match what we provided to our server.
Learn more about the Apollo Studio Explorer

is an open-source tool for querying your GraphQL server. It provides fewer features than the Apollo Studio Explorer, but it does everything we need for this tutorial. It's also included in every Apollo Server installation.
in your browser to open GraphQL Playground. To introspect your server's schema, click the
Your schema's queries, mutations, and object type definitions appear:

properties.alt: More details on a Schema Type

children.value: Our server now knows which GraphQL types and operations it supports, but it doesn't know where to obtain the data to respond to those operations. Next, we'll connect our server to two data sources.
